raw_text:
PlayStation 3 chip to be unveiled
 
 Details of the chip designed to power Sony's PlayStation 3 console will be released in San Francisco on Monday.
 
 Sony, IBM and Toshiba, who have been working on the Cell processor for three years, will unveil the chip at a technology conference. The chip is reported to be up to 10 times faster than current processors. It is being designed for use in graphics workstations, the new PlayStation console, and has been described as a supercomputer on a chip. Sony has said the Cell processor could be used to bridge the gap between movies and video games. Special effects and graphics designed for films could be ported for use directly in a video game, Sony told an audience at the E3 exhibition in Los Angeles last year.
 
 Cell could also be marketed as an ideal technology for televisions and supercomputers, and everything in between, said Kevin Krewell, the editor in chief of Microprocessor Report. The chip will be made of several different processing cores that work on tasks together. The PlayStation 3 is expected in 2006 but developers are expecting to get prototypes early next year to tune games that will appear on it at launch. Details of the chip will be released at the International Solid State Circuits Conference in San Francisco. Some details have already emerged, however. When put inside powerful computer servers, the Cell consortium expects it to be capable of handling 16 trillion floating point operations, or calculations, every second.
 
 The chip has also been refined to be able to handle the detailed graphics common in games and the data demands of films and broadband media. IBM said it would start producing the chip in early 2005 at manufacturing plants in the US. The first machines off the line using the Cell processor will be computer workstations and servers. A working version of the PS3 is due to be shown off in May 2005 but a full launch of the next generation console is not expected to start until 2006. "In the future, all forms of digital content will be converged and fused onto the broadband network," said Ken Kutaragi, chief operating officer of Sony, said last year. "Current PC architecture is nearing its limits," he added.
llama3.2:1b: Sony's PlayStation 3 chip is set to be unveiled in San Francisco on Monday. The chip, designed by IBM and Toshiba for use in graphics workstations and the new console, will be up to 10 times faster than current processors and capable of handling 16 trillion calculations per second. It is being marketed as a supercomputer on a chip and could enable special effects and graphics directly in video games. Details of the chip will be released at the International Solid State Circuits Conference.
llama3.2:3b: Sony, IBM and Toshiba to unveil Cell processor chip designed for PlayStation 3 console in San Francisco on Monday, reported to be up to 10 times faster than current processors. The chip has been described as a supercomputer on a chip and will also be used in graphics workstations, televisions and supercomputers, with capabilities of handling 16 trillion floating point operations every second.
gemma2:2b: Sony will unveil details of the Cell processor designed for the PlayStation 3 at an International Solid State Circuits Conference in San Francisco on Monday. The chip, reported to be up to ten times faster than current processors, aims to bridge the gap between movies and video games by allowing filmmakers' special effects and graphics to be directly used in video game development.  The Cell processor is designed for use in graphics workstations, PlayStation 3 consoles, and will be made of multiple processing cores that work together. IBM will begin producing the chip in early 2005 at US manufacturing plants. The first machines using the Cell processor will be computer workstations and servers, with a working version of the PS3 due to be shown off in May 2005.  Full launch of the next-generation console is expected in 2006.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Key points: 
- PlayStation 3 chip to be unveiled in San Francisco.
- The Cell processor from Sony, IBM and Toshiba designed for graphics workstations.
- Cell could power video games, including movies.
- Cell has been refined to handle detailed graphics and data demands of digital content.
- The full launch of the next-generation PlayStation console is not expected until 2006.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Sony's PlayStation 3 chip designed to power next-generation console will be unveiled at International Solid State Circuits Conference in San Francisco on Monday. It's up to 10 times faster than current processors and will be used for graphics workstations, new PlayStation console, and supercomputing. Sony aims for it to bridge movies and games' special effects and data demands. Cell chip uses multiple processing cores working together and is also marketed as ideal technology for televisions and PCs. It's expected in 2006 but prototypes will be shown in early 2005, with PS3 launch not until 2006. IBM started producing the chip in US plants in early 2005.
qwen2.5:3b: Details of the Cell processor designed for powering Sony's PlayStation 3 console will be unveiled in San Francisco on Monday. Developed by Sony, IBM, and Toshiba over three years, the chip is reportedly up to ten times faster than current processors. It can handle both graphics workstations and games, as well as serve potential markets such as televisions and supercomputers. The International Solid State Circuits Conference will release more details of the chip's capabilities, including its ability to perform 16 trillion floating point operations per second in powerful computer servers. Production of the processor is set to begin early 2005 at US manufacturing plants, with a working PlayStation 3 prototype due for public display in May 2005 and full launch expected in 2006. Sony predicts convergence of all digital content onto broadband networks in the future.
opencoder:1.5b:
The PlayStation 3 chip will be unveiled by several tech companies working on a Cell processor for three years.

The chip will be designed to power Sony's new console and up to 10 times faster than current processors, capable of handling graphics workstations, the cell processor, and even special effects for films. The console has been described as a supercomputer on a chip. It will allow movies and video games to run smoother through special effects, bringing them closer to real-time processing.

The Cell could also be marketed as an ideal technology for televisions and supercomputers, being a versatile tool for managing digital content with high-speed calculations, even in confined environments. 

The chip is made of several cores that work together to handle complex tasks at once, making it suitable for scaling computing power across multiple machines.

Expect prototypes to be released early this year as well as more detailed technical reports. The upcoming release promises to bring groundbreaking gaming performance and versatile connectivity options, set new benchmarks in the console industry.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should preserve key ideas and details as faithfully as possible. The main points are:

1. The PlayStation 3 chip will be unveiled in San Francisco on Monday.
2. Sony, IBM, and Toshiba have been working on the Cell processor for three years.
3. The Cell processor is designed to power the new PlayStation 3 console.
4. The Cell processor could be used to bridge the gap between movies and video games.
5. Special effects and graphics designed for films could be ported for use directly in a video game.
6. The chip will be made of several different processing cores that work together.
7. The PlayStation 3 is expected in 2006 but developers are expecting to get prototypes early next year to tune games that will appear on it at launch.
8. When put inside powerful computer servers, the Cell processor can handle detailed graphics common in games and data demands of films and broadband media.
9. IBM said it would start producing the chip in early 2005 at manufacturing plants in the US.
10. A working version of the PS3 is due to be shown off in May 2005 but a full launch of the next generation console is not expected to start until 2006.

IBM started manufacturing in 2005, with initial machines for workstations/servers now being operational. Sony expects to show off the PS3 in May but launch of the next-gen console isn't until 2006.

The chip is meant to converge digital content onto a common network, replacing current PC architectures which are getting closer to their limits. They mentioned that Sony's approach could bridge film and gaming.

The PlayStation 3 chip will be unveiled in San Francisco, targeting graphics workstations and the console itself, expected to deliver performance up to ten times faster than current processors. The Cell processor is designed for use in televisions, supercomputers, and bridging film and video game genres. Sony, IBM, and Toshiba are collaborating on this chip, which will be showcased at a tech conference. The Cell processor has the capability to handle 16 trillion floating point operations per second on powerful servers. IBM plans to start manufacturing by early 2005, with initial machines for workstations/servers operational now. Sony expects to demonstrate the PS3 in May 2005 but plans to launch its next-gen console in 2006. The chip aims to converge digital content onto a common network, replacing current PC architectures which are nearing their limits.
tinyllama:1.1b: A new chip designed to power the PlayStation 3 console has been unveiled and will reportedly be up to 10 times faster than current processors. The Cell processor, which was developed by Sony, IBM, and Toshiba over three years, is said to perform tasks together in a processing core that allows games to appear on screens within seconds. The chip is designed for use in graphics-intensive applications, such as video games or movies, but could also be used for televisions and supercomputers. While developers are waiting for prototype units to be released at the International Solid State Circuits Conference next year, some details of the Cell processor have already emerged. The chip is reportedly capable of handling 16 trillion floating point operations per second (FLOPS), or calculations, every second. It also has been refined to handle detailed graphics commonly found in games and data demands of films and broadband media. A working version of the PlayStation 3 will be shown off in May 2005 but a full launch is not expected to start until 2006.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The PlayStation 3 (PS3) is set to have an impressive new chip that could revolutionize computing. This new chip has been designed by a team led by Kevin Krewell from Microprocessor Report and involves several processors working together to perform tasks. Some of the most significant features of the chip include its potential ability to handle 16 trillion floating point operations per second, which is capable of handling detailed graphics in games and the data demands of films and broadband media. The PS3 will be made of several different processing cores that work together to perform tasks simultaneously. This innovation will allow for faster reaction times, better graphics, and increased reliability compared to current computing systems.

It could be used to improve video games, televisions, and supercomputers. The first working versions of this chip will go into computer workstations and servers in early

orca-mini:3b: PlayStation 3 will be unveiled in San Francisco with a new supercomputer-on-a-chip called Cell designed by Sony, IBM and Toshiba. The chip is reported to be 10 times faster than current processors and can handle 16 trillion floating point operations per second. It will be used in graphics workstations, the new PlayStation console, and has been described as a supercomputer on a chip. Developers are expecting prototypes of the PS3 to arrive early next year to tune games that will appear on it at launch. The chip is expected to be used in everything from televisions to supercomputers, and everything in between.
hermes3:3b: PlayStation 3 Cell chip to be unveiled in San Fran, up to 10x faster than current processors; designed for PS3 console, graphics workstations, televisions & supercomputers.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Sony, IBM, and Toshiba will unveil the PlayStation 3 chip at a technology conference in San Francisco; reports say it's up to 10 times faster than current processors and can be used for graphics workstations, console gaming, special effects in films, TVs, supercomputers, and more. The chip has multiple processing cores working simultaneously. Production began in early 2005, with initial machines producing computer workstations and servers; a full launch of the next-gen PlayStation 3 is expected in 2006.
stablelm2:1.6b: PlayStation 3 chip details to be revealed by Sony, IBM, and Toshiba at a tech conference in San Francisco. The Cell processor, designed for use in graphics workstations, will be up to twice as fast as current processors, with applications in video games, televisions, supercomputers, and film industries. Initial production expected in 2015, with prototypes possibly in development by next year.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Sony, IBM, and Toshiba have collaborated for three years to develop the Cell processor, a high-performance chip designed for the PlayStation 3 console and capable of running complex graphics, video games, and media. This supercomputer-on-a-chip is reportedly up to 10 times faster than current processors, handling 16 trillion floating point operations per second when integrated into powerful servers. The Cell processor features multiple processing cores working together for enhanced performance in graphics, film special effects, and broadband data demands. Details of the chip will be unveiled at the International Solid State Circuits Conference in San Francisco. Early 2005 is expected for mass production by IBM, with the first devices being computer workstations and servers. The PlayStation 3, anticipated for launch in 2006, is expected to benefit from these advancements, potentially merging various digital content onto broadband networks as current PC architecture nears its limits.

The chip, reportedly up to 10 times faster than current processors, is described as a "supercomputer on a chip" and could bridge the gap between movies and video games by enabling film-quality graphics in games. It may also be used in televisions, supercomputers, and other devices. The PlayStation 3 is expected in 2006, with developers receiving prototypes in 2005. The chip, capable of 16 trillion calculations per second, will first be used in computer workstations and servers, with IBM beginning production in early 2005. Sony sees the Cell processor as key to the future of digital content and broadband networks.
reference: Sony, IBM and Toshiba, who have been working on the Cell processor for three years, will unveil the chip at a technology conference.It is being designed for use in graphics workstations, the new PlayStation console, and has been described as a supercomputer on a chip.Details of the chip designed to power Sony's PlayStation 3 console will be released in San Francisco on Monday.Sony has said the Cell processor could be used to bridge the gap between movies and video games.IBM said it would start producing the chip in early 2005 at manufacturing plants in the US.The chip has also been refined to be able to handle the detailed graphics common in games and the data demands of films and broadband media.The chip is reported to be up to 10 times faster than current processors.Details of the chip will be released at the International Solid State Circuits Conference in San Francisco.
